description: id as defined by the genetics laboratory, needs to be unique (e.g. I1234, BOT001), needs to fit to the values in the poseidon package .fam file, if multiple datasets exist for the same individual different IDs are required (e.g. loschbour_snpAD)

ideally Eisenmann rule + underscore flags, e.g. to annotate relatives or outliers or low coverage, multiple entries separated by ; to accommodate different labels, value must equal the group name in the .fam file (in case of multiple entries the first one)
id as defined by the provider/owner of a sample (e.g. grave 40 skeleton 2)
present-day political country
unspecified location information like administrative or topographic region or mountains/rivers/lakes/cities nearby
site name
latitude with up to 5 places after the decimal point
longitude with up to 5 places after the decimal point
“C14“ if directly from the individual, “contextual“ if based on archaeology or other C14 dates from the site, “modern” for present-day individuals
labnr of C14 date, multiple values separated by ; in case of multiple dates
uncalibrated years BP (as in before 1950AD), as reported by C14 labs, multiple values separated by ; in the same order as Date_C14_Labnr in case of multiple dates
standard deviation (1 sigma ±), as reported by C14 labs, multiple values separated by ; in the same order as Date_C14_Labnr in case of multiple dates
calibrated median age for C14 dates, or simple mid-points for archaeological intervals, 2000 for modern samples
lower (older) bound for the age, negative numbers for BC, positive numbers for AD, in case of C14 dates 95% interval post calibration, 2000 for modern samples
upper (more recent) bound for the age, negative numbers for BC, positive numbers for AD, in case of C14 dates 95% interval post calibration, 2000 for modern samples
“F“, “M“ or “U“ because eigenstrat and plink formats only support these three. Edge cases (XXY, XYY, X0) are undefined and should be grouped as F, M or U, with a note added
mitochondrial haplogroup after phylotree.org as reported by Haplofind or Haplogrep
Y-chromosome haplogroup reported as published, for internal data, please follow syntax with main branch + most terminal derived Y-SNP (e.g. R1b-P312)
skeletal/tissue/source elements, specific bone name should be reported with an underscore (e.g. bone_phalanx), multiple values separated by ; in case of multiple libraries
number of libraries
specifics of data generation method, multiple values separated by ;
“mixed” in case multiple libraries with different UDG treatment were merged
“ds” for double stranded, “ss” for single stranded, “mixed” in case multiple libraries with different protocols were merged
ploidy of the genotypes
URL pointing to a description of the pipeline used to generate the genotype data from the source data
% endogenous DNA as estimated from SG libraries (before capture), as for example estimated by EAGER, not on target and no quality filter, in case of multiple libraries report only the highest value
number of SNPs covered
average X-fold coverage across 1240K SNP sites after quality filtering (internal data), NOT the % SNPs of 1.2M possible
% damage on 5' end for the main shotgun library used for sequencing and/or capture, in case of multiple libraries report a value from the merged read alignment
if male for captured library, in case of multiple libraries report a value from the merged read alignment
standard error of ANGSD X contamination estimate, in case of multiple libraries report a value from the merged read alignment
mitochondrial contamination rate as estimated by ContamMix and/or Schmutzi, in case of multiple libraries report a value from the merged read alignment
Standard error of ContamMix/Schmutzi estimate, in case of multiple libraries report a value from the merged read alignment

ENA or SRA Accession ID(s) pointing to the source data used to generate the genotyping data. If multiple are given they should be arranged by descending specificity (e.g. project id > sample id > sequencing run id).
Project lead or first author
bibtex key (e.g. “AuthorJournalYear“) or “unpublished“
wildcard comments. e.g. note down aneuploidies here
Arbitrary tags separated by ; (e.g. for custom sorting purposes)
